section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, sing a song about weather, and introduce vocabulary (sneak, wondering).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, What could Cloudette do that the bigger clouds couldn’t do?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use appropriate tone of voice; Join in singing, rhyming, and word play; Use verbal and nonverbal conversation and group discussion rules; Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand and use a growing number of story words; Understand and use a growing number of common phrases.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Relate own experiences to those in books.
Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen in the sky; Describe what happens when the earth or sky changes.
Begin to recognize common three-dimensional shapes, describing them as balls, boxes, cans, and cones.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Show children a series of pictures and talk about the different types of weather they see in each one.
Challenge children to use their bodies to show how they’d act in each type of weather.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find books that show pictures of different kinds of weather?
Pretend to be a cloud floating in the sky. What shape would you like to be?
Can you see clouds from the window? What shapes are they?
Draw a picture of rain clouds with lightning during a thunderstorm.
What materials can you use to make a cloud? How about a flash of lightning?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word weather? Can you write that letter?
Can you use blocks to build a place outside where people can stay dry during a rainstorm?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder make plans and introduce vocabulary (blue, important).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Cloudette.
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use appropriate tone of voice; Use verbal and nonverbal conversation and group discussion rules; Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand and use a growing number of story words; Understand and use a growing number of common phrases.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen in the sky; Describe what happens when the earth or sky changes.
Identify and create common features in the natural environment, such as hills, rivers, roads, lakes, and familiar buildings.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Show children a series of pictures of clothing that is appropriate for either hot or cold weather.
Have children sort each item into a “hot” or “cold” pile and discuss how people plan for different weather conditions.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find in a book a picture of a windy day?
Pretend to make hot soup to drink on a cold day. Serve some to your friends.
Can you compare Cloudette to the other clouds? Can you show it in a picture?
What is your favorite thing to do outdoors on a hot day? Draw it.
Can you make a snowman on a sheet of paper?
What letter does the word cloud start with? What about the word rain?
Build a snow castle for you and a friend. How big will it be? What shape will it be?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Cloudette by Tom Lichtenheld. Copyright © 2011 by Tom Lichtenheld. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Henry Holt and Company, an imprint of Macmillan Publishing Group, LLC. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension strategy Make a Connection, engage children in a movement activity about weather, and introduce vocabulary (cozy, storm).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Cloudette. Ask the guiding question, What did Cloudette want to do that the bigger clouds could do?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use appropriate tone of voice; Use verbal and nonverbal conversation and group discussion rules; Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Understand and use a growing number of story words; Understand and use a growing number of common phrases.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Tolerate frustration as a step to learning.
Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen in the sky.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Review and discuss with children pictures of different types of weather.
Discuss what you would see and do and how you would feel in each type of weather.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How would that story be different if the weather were different?
Can you show me how you would walk down the sidewalk on a very windy day?
Can you think of a way to measure the rain? How could you measure snow?
Can you make up a song about clouds? Draw a picture to go with it.
How many different colors can you use to paint the sun?
What letters would you use to spell the word snow?
Can you build a snowman out of blocks? How tall will it be?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Cloudette by Tom Lichtenheld. Copyright © 2011 by Tom Lichtenheld. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Henry Holt and Company, an imprint of Macmillan Publishing Group, LLC.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: What’s the Weather?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about what children have learned about clouds and weather, sing a song about weather, and introduce vocabulary words (snowy, windy).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts What’s the Weather? and Cloudette.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use appropriate tone of voice; Join in singing, rhyming, and word play; Use verbal and nonverbal conversation and group discussion rules; Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand and use a growing number of story words; Understand and use a growing number of common phrases.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen in the sky; Describe what happens when the earth or sky changes.
Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Provide children with blank Daily Weather books for them to record their observations about the weather they see.
Help children with making and recording observations.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Find a book about weather. What kinds of weather does it show?
Pretend to jump in a puddle. How does it feel?
Count how many bigger clouds talk to Cloudette in the book.
What words rhyme with rain? with sleet? with snow?
Can you make a cover for your Daily Weather book? What will you show on the cover?
Can you spell the word cloud? What do you think is the first letter? What do you think is the last letter?
Build a place where people can go when it is raining.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Cloudette by Tom Lichtenheld. Copyright © 2011 by Tom Lichtenheld. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Henry Holt and Company, an imprint of Macmillan Publishing Group, LLC.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children do a movement activity about their favorite type of weather and introduce vocabulary (perfect, exhausted).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book. Ask, “What important thing did Cloudette do?”
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use appropriate tone of voice; Join in singing, rhyming, and word play; Use verbal and nonverbal conversation and group discussion rules.
Understand and use a growing number of story words; Understand and use a growing number of common phrases.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen in the sky.
Act out to recreate and tell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: What is your favorite type of weather? Why?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing/drawing to display next week.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find a story that takes place on a sunny day?
Pretend you are on TV. Tell people what the weather will be like tomorrow and what they should wear when they go outside.
Pretend you are in a bathtub full of water. What are two things that sink? What are two things that float?
Can you draw a picture of the saying, “It’s raining cats and dogs”?
Draw and color a rainbow.
Thunder makes the sound BOOM. Can you find the first letter in boom? Can you find the last letter?
Can you make a rainbow out of blocks?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Match language to social contexts.
Demonstrate knowledge of verbal conversational rules.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Identify, observe, and discuss objects in the sky.
Observe and discuss what happens during changes in the earth and sky.
common shapes.
Match language to social contexts.
Investigate and demonstrate growing understanding of the sounds and intonation of language.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Identify, observe, and discuss objects in the sky.
Observe and describe what happens during changes in the earth and sky.
Identify and create common features in the natural environment.
Match language to social contexts.
Demonstrate knowledge of verbal conversational rules.
Investigate and demonstrate growing understanding of the sounds and intonation of language.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Tolerate frustration as a step to learning.
Identify, observe, and discuss objects in the sky.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
Match language to social contexts.
Investigate and demonstrate growing understanding of the sounds and intonation of language.
Demonstrate knowledge of verbal conversational rules.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Identify, observe, and discuss objects in the sky.
Observe and discuss what happens during changes in the earth and sky.
Count 1–10 items, with one count per item.
Match language to social contexts.
Investigate and demonstrate growing understanding of the sounds and intonation of language.
Demonstrate knowledge of nonverbal conversational rules.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Make plans and take steps toward a goal.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language, and verbally share meaning.
Identify, observe, and discuss objects in the sky.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
